Time to Act
The main issue of the past five days of unrest has
been the question of military recruiters on campu
s.
Through attempts to find a solution to the dilemma
by
the Student Affairs Committee, the News-Letter
and
President Gordon, several things have become clear. First,
that Dr. Gordon is personally opposed to eliminating oncampus recruiting. Second, that he has allowed his personal feelings to interfere with his performance as the
chief executive officer of this University. Third, that
the
intransigence of his position has amplified already high
tensions on campus and, more than any other factor,
has led to a call for a general strike.
If Dr. Gordon had his way, he would ride the status
quo and delay the matter of a decision on military recruiting indefinitely. He has rejected or ignored all proposals
.that do not match his original referendum specifications
of last Friday. And he has made it clear that he will not
accept settlements of University governance questions
"on the basis of one student vote equals one faculty vote."
President Gordon chose not to respond to the NewsLetter's demand for a binding one man-one vote studentfaculty referendum. With the News-Letter plan, as with
all other campus elections, a majority of those voting
would be sufficient to determine a winner. Inexplicably,
Dr. Gordon set up this election differently. He has repeatedly rejected the notion of plurality wins.
He also chose to ignore a Monday night Student
Affairs Committee resolution banning recruiting on campus. This occurred only hours after he assigned the Committee the task of formulating a solution to the recruitment question. Obviously he had falsely hoped that the
SAC would approve his referendum plan. Under that
plan, the SAC would have had the power, in Gordon's
words, "to determine the actual decision if the referendum
itself did not provide a clear showing of campus community opinion." Both SC President John Guess and Grad
Student Organization President Bob Cotter had previously
declined to appoint an ad hoc committee with the powers
described above.
When the SAC passed its resolution banning recruiting, it requested a public "yes or no" answer from Dr.
Gordon yesterday. Rather than respond, the President
elected to ignore a crowd of some 200 student and faculty
members waiting to receive his reply. Dr. Gordon handed
a prepared statement to Dean-elect George Benton and
left for a meeting which he obviously felt was more important. His statement, circumventing the question of the
SAC resolution, called again on the SAC to endorse and
take charge of a referendum conducted on the President's
terms—the very same proposition which the same committee had defeated the night before.
Gordon has made many mistakes in the past several
days and too few good judgments to counterbalance them.
He must be lauded for one thing only--his removal of
a
restrictive court injunction. But that can only be classed
as the belated correction of a costly mistake which exacerbated tensions and mistrust between demonstrators
and the administration.
There are now no longer any alternative "legitimate"
channels to which the protestors can appeal. For the past
two years, all student "victories" including the calendar
reform issue, the Levering Hall budget controversy and
the Freshman gym boycott have been won only when
students exerted pressure outside normal channels. On
the other hand, the discipline code, for example, was
taken through official channels all the way. The SAC
held hearings and drew up a code, but, in the end, Dr.
Gordon intervened with assumed authority and changed
it to his liking.
Demonstration after demonstration has been organized since Friday, but no substantive or procedural gains
have been made. The only result has been frustration for
those involved. Most of us, including those who do not see
the recruitment issue as crucial, have been frustrated at one
time or another at the hands of Hopkins. Whether the
problem be parking, a lack of good courses or the elimination of classified research, most of the frustration
can be traced to the lack of an adequate governance system.
The administration's arrogance of power must be
met by stern student-faculty action. A general strike can
be used to redress our grievances with an audience that
won't be able to afford not to listen. We endorse the
statement of the Hopkins Strike Committee and urge all
students to boycott classes and participate in strike activities. We also call on the faculty to support their students
by canceling classes and taking part in the activities.

The crisis of the environment constitutes a challenge to many of our most cherished American
beliefs, such as the idea of technological progress
as a general good, the importance of individual
initiative in economic development as an element
of freedom and the view that the general public
weal is adequately safeguarded from environ
mental degradation by existing forms of government.
Challenging of these beliefs is of recent origin,
and there is not only a lack of people technically
qualified to evaluate environmental problems but
also there is a considerable inertia toward recognizing these problems in people today, many of
whom grew up in a time when work toward an indefinitely expanding economy was an important
article of faith. College students have a great opportunity, and even an obligation,to prepare themselves to assume major roles in the next decades
in dealing with these complicated issues.
Training in science, engineering, sociology,
urban planning, coupled with a motivation to deal
with immediate and long-range aspects of environmental protection will be needed. In addition we
will need highly motivated people who can help
review and revise the process of making public
decisions with respect to environmental protection. Such governmental processes as exist now
are rudimentary and inadequate to the great tasks
ahead.

No Simple Answers

simple answers will suffice to check or reverse
environmental deterioration. It is unrealistic in
America to expect population stabilization before
forty or fifty years, and in the meantime more
urgent matters must be faced immediately. A
morally enlightened society depends, as a first
requirement, on adequate food supplies and shelter, production and distribution of food and the
design and location of acceptable living space will
carry environmental price tags that must be understood and kept to acceptable levels.
Our technologically advanced society depends
for high productivity on a whole series of interlocking industries. Industrial alternatives less

the means and will for switching to better methods

as Garrett Hardin has stated.

been the question of military recruiters on campu

President Gordon, several things have become clear. First,

chief executive officer of this University. Third, that
the
intransigence of his position has amplified already high
tensions on campus and, more than any other factor,
has led to a call for a general strike.
If Dr. Gordon had his way, he would ride the status
quo and delay the matter of a decision on military recruiting indefinitely. He has rejected or ignored all proposals
.that do not match his original referendum specifications
of last Friday. And he has made it clear that he will not
accept settlements of University governance questions
"on the basis of one student vote equals one faculty vote."
President Gordon chose not to respond to the NewsLetter's demand for a binding one man-one vote studentfaculty referendum. With the News-Letter plan, as with
all other campus elections, a majority of those voting
would be sufficient to determine a winner. Inexplicably,
Dr. Gordon set up this election differently. He has repeatedly rejected the notion of plurality wins.

Affairs Committee resolution banning recruiting on campus. This occurred only hours after he assigned the Committee the task of formulating a solution to the recruitment question. Obviously he had falsely hoped that the
SAC would approve his referendum plan. Under that
plan, the SAC would have had the power, in Gordon's
words, "to determine the actual decision if the referendum
itself did not provide a clear showing of campus community opinion." Both SC President John Guess and Grad
Student Organization President Bob Cotter had previously
declined to appoint an ad hoc committee with the powers
described above.

Gordon yesterday. Rather than respond, the President
elected to ignore a crowd of some 200 student and faculty
members waiting to receive his reply. Dr. Gordon handed
a prepared statement to Dean-elect George Benton and
left for a meeting which he obviously felt was more important. His statement, circumventing the question of the
SAC resolution, called again on the SAC to endorse and
take charge of a referendum conducted on the President's
terms—the very same proposition which the same committee had defeated the night before.

days and too few good judgments to counterbalance them.
He must be lauded for one thing only--his removal of
a
restrictive court injunction. But that can only be classed
as the belated correction of a costly mistake which exacerbated tensions and mistrust between demonstrators
and the administration.

channels to which the protestors can appeal. For the past
two years, all student "victories" including the calendar
reform issue, the Levering Hall budget controversy and
the Freshman gym boycott have been won only when
students exerted pressure outside normal channels. On
the other hand, the discipline code, for example, was
taken through official channels all the way. The SAC
held hearings and drew up a code, but, in the end, Dr.
Gordon intervened with assumed authority and changed
it to his liking.

have been made. The only result has been frustration for
those involved. Most of us, including those who do not see
the recruitment issue as crucial, have been frustrated at one
time or another at the hands of Hopkins. Whether the
problem be parking, a lack of good courses or the elimination of classified research, most of the frustration
can be traced to the lack of an adequate governance system.
The administration's arrogance of power must be
met by stern student-faculty action. A general strike can
be used to redress our grievances with an audience that
won't be able to afford not to listen. We endorse the
statement of the Hopkins Strike Committee and urge all
students to boycott classes and participate in strike activities. We also call on the faculty to support their students
by canceling classes and taking part in the activities.

The crisis of the environment constitutes a challenge to many of our most cherished American
beliefs, such as the idea of technological progress
as a general good, the importance of individual
initiative in economic development as an element
of freedom and the view that the general public
weal is adequately safeguarded from environ
mental degradation by existing forms of government.
Challenging of these beliefs is of recent origin,
and there is not only a lack of people technically
qualified to evaluate environmental problems but
also there is a considerable inertia toward recognizing these problems in people today, many of
whom grew up in a time when work toward an indefinitely expanding economy was an important
article of faith. College students have a great opportunity, and even an obligation,to prepare themselves to assume major roles in the next decades
in dealing with these complicated issues.
Training in science, engineering, sociology,
urban planning, coupled with a motivation to deal
with immediate and long-range aspects of environmental protection will be needed. In addition we
will need highly motivated people who can help
review and revise the process of making public
decisions with respect to environmental protection. Such governmental processes as exist now
are rudimentary and inadequate to the great tasks
ahead.

No Simple Answers
Students should not be misled into thinking that
simple answers will suffice to check or reverse
environmental deterioration. It is unrealistic in
America to expect population stabilization before
forty or fifty years, and in the meantime more
urgent matters must be faced immediately. A
morally enlightened society depends, as a first
requirement, on adequate food supplies and shelter, production and distribution of food and the
design and location of acceptable living space will
carry environmental price tags that must be understood and kept to acceptable levels.
Our technologically advanced society depends
for high productivity on a whole series of interlocking industries. Industrial alternatives less
hazardous to the environment must be sought, and
the means and will for switching to better methods
of recycling limited resources must be found.
There must be a way developed to safeguard individual freedom within a framework of group respons
ibility, or "mutual coercion, mutally agreed upon"
as Garrett Hardin has stated.

day at the plate, along with four runs
scored by Dennis O'Neill, highlighted the
Saturday game.

Thorne Optimistic

Thorne had this to say: "I think we have
An excellent ballclub. If we continue to
work on our fundamentals and cut down
even more on our errors, there's no
telling how far we'll go."
